title: Job Chapter 40 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 40 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 40 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 40.

questions.question: Who answered Job in Job 40:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Job 40:1 states, 'Moreover the LORD answered Job, and said,' indicating it was the LORD who answered.

questions.question: According to Job 40:2, what is asked about contending with the Almighty?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall he instruct Him?
questions.explanation: Job 40:2 asks, 'Shall he that contendeth with the Almighty instruct him?'

questions.question: What did Job say about himself in Job 40:4?
questions.correctAnswer: I am vile
questions.explanation: In Job 40:4, Job says, 'Behold, I am vile; what shall I answer thee?'

questions.question: How many times did Job say he had spoken before deciding not to answer further? (Job 40:5)
questions.correctAnswer: Once and twice
questions.explanation: Job 40:5 states, 'Once have I spoken; but I will not answer: yea, twice; but I will proceed no further.'

questions.question: In Job 40:7, what does the LORD command Job to do?
options: Gird up thy loins like a man
questions.correctAnswer: Gird up thy loins like a man
questions.explanation: Job 40:7 says, 'Gird up thy loins now like a man: I will demand of thee.'

questions.question: According to Job 40:9, what is asked about Job's arm?
options: Hast thou an arm like God?
questions.correctAnswer: Hast thou an arm like God?
questions.explanation: Job 40:9 asks, 'Hast thou an arm like God? or canst thou thunder with a voice like him?'

questions.question: What does the LORD tell Job to deck himself with in Job 40:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Majesty and excellency
questions.explanation: Job 40:10 says, 'Deck thyself now with majesty and excellency; and array thyself with glory and beauty.'

questions.question: Who is described as eating grass like an ox in Job 40:15?
questions.correctAnswer: Behemoth
questions.explanation: Job 40:15 states, 'Behold now behemoth, which I made with thee; he eateth grass as an ox.'

questions.question: What part of Behemoth is compared to a cedar in Job 40:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Tail
questions.explanation: Job 40:17 says, 'He moveth his tail like a cedar.'

questions.question: According to Job 40:18, Behemoth's bones are like what materials?
questions.correctAnswer: Brass and iron
questions.explanation: Job 40:18 describes, 'His bones are as strong pieces of brass; his bones are like bars of iron.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 40:23 states that Behemoth drinks up a river and hastens.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 40:23 states, 'Behold, he drinketh up a river, and hasteth not,' meaning he drinks without hasting.

questions.question: True or False: In Job 40:21, Behemoth lies under shady trees and in the covert of the reed.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 40:21 states, 'He lieth under the shady trees, in the covert of the reed, and fens.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 40:14 says that if Job can bring down the proud, God will confess that Job's own right hand can save him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 40:14 states, 'Then will I also confess unto thee that thine own right hand can save thee.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Job 40:11: 'Cast abroad the rage of thy wrath: and behold every one that is ______, and abase him.'
questions.correctAnswer: proud
questions.explanation: Job 40:11 says, 'Cast abroad the rage of thy wrath: and behold every one that is proud, and abase him.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Job 40:24: 'He taketh it with his eyes: his nose pierceth through ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: snares
questions.explanation: Job 40:24 states, 'He taketh it with his eyes: his nose pierceth through snares.'

medium.title: Job Chapter 40 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 40 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Job 40:2-5, what biblical truth would you share about responding to God during difficult times?
options: We should humbly acknowledge our limitations and refrain from arguing with God.
We should insist on our own understanding above God's counsel.
We should ignore God's questions and remain silent.
We should demand answers from God immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: We should humbly acknowledge our limitations and refrain from arguing with God.
questions.explanation: Job acknowledges his vileness and decides not to further answer God (Job 40:3-5). This teaches humility and trust even without full understanding, as God challenges Job in Job 40:2.

questions.question: How does Job 40:7-8 teach us about humility and respect toward God's judgment?
options: It reminds us not to question God's judgment but to submit and trust His righteousness.
It encourages us to demand explanations from God about His decisions.
It tells us to judge God by our own standards of fairness.
It advises us to ignore God's commands when we disagree.
questions.correctAnswer: It reminds us not to question God's judgment but to submit and trust His righteousness.
questions.explanation: God asks Job if he will disannul His judgment or condemn Him to seem righteous, teaching submission and trust in God's just decisions (Job 40:7-8).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with pride. Based on Job 40:10-12, what practical advice does this passage provide?
options: We should clothe ourselves with humility and bring down the proud.
We should flaunt our achievements to humble others.
We should ignore pride in ourselves and others.
We should only focus on our own pride without addressing others.
questions.correctAnswer: We should clothe ourselves with humility and bring down the proud.
questions.explanation: God commands to array oneself with majesty and glory and to abase the proud, emphasizing humility and opposition to pride (Job 40:10-12).

questions.question: How does Job 40:13-14 illustrate the importance of recognizing God’s power over the wicked and trusting in His salvation?
options: It shows that God can overpower the wicked and that our salvation ultimately depends on Him.
It suggests that we can save ourselves without God’s help.
It teaches us to seek revenge on the wicked ourselves.
It tells us to ignore the wicked and focus only on ourselves.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that God can overpower the wicked and that our salvation ultimately depends on Him.
questions.explanation: The passage describes God binding and hiding the wicked, and only then will He acknowledge our own power to save, emphasizing dependence on God’s power (Job 40:13-14).

questions.question: What lesson about God's creation and human humility is taught in Job 40:15-18 through the description of Behemoth?
options: God’s creations are majestic and powerful, reminding us to be humble before Him.
Humans are more powerful than any creature God made.
Behemoth symbolizes human strength and self-reliance.
We should fear all animals more than God.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s creations are majestic and powerful, reminding us to be humble before Him.
questions.explanation: The description of Behemoth’s strength and majesty illustrates God’s sovereign power in creation, teaching humility in human perspective (Job 40:15-18).

questions.question: Based on Job 40:19-20, how should believers respond to God's control over all creation?
options: With trust and confidence in His supreme authority over all things.
By doubting His power and trying to control creation ourselves.
By ignoring His workings in nature.
By fearing creation more than the Creator.
questions.correctAnswer: With trust and confidence in His supreme authority over all things.
questions.explanation: God is described as the maker of Behemoth and controller of the mountains that feed him, teaching trust in God's sovereign care (Job 40:19-20).

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by life’s challenges. What encouragement does Job 40:21-22 provide about finding rest and peace?
options: God provides places of rest and protection, like shady trees and quiet waters.
We must struggle alone without seeking shelter.
Rest is only found through worldly possessions.
questions.correctAnswer: God provides places of rest and protection, like shady trees and quiet waters.
questions.explanation: The imagery of Behemoth resting under shady trees and willows by brooks symbolizes God’s provision of peace and refuge (Job 40:21-22).

questions.question: How does Job 40:23 teach believers about trusting God’s provision even in seemingly impossible situations?
options: Behemoth drinks a whole river without haste, trusting its availability, teaching us to trust God’s provision.
We should rely only on our own efforts to meet needs.
Provision is scarce and cannot be trusted.
We must constantly worry about resources.
questions.correctAnswer: Behemoth drinks a whole river without haste, trusting its availability, teaching us to trust God’s provision.
questions.explanation: The text shows the animal trusting to draw Jordan into its mouth, illustrating faith in steady provision (Job 40:23).

questions.question: True or False: Job 40:9 suggests that humans have the same power as God to thunder with a voice like His.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse questions if Job has an arm like God or can thunder like Him, implying humans do not share God's power (Job 40:9).

questions.question: True or False: Job 40:4-5 shows Job's humility as he decides to stop arguing with God after speaking twice.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job acknowledges his vileness and decides not to answer further after speaking twice, demonstrating humility (Job 40:4-5).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Job 40:7 commands Job to 'Gird up thy ______ like a man' and be ready to answer God's demand.
questions.correctAnswer: loins
questions.explanation: God instructs Job to gird up his loins like a man, symbolizing readiness and courage (Job 40:7).

questions.question: How can Job 40:11-12 inform our attitude toward those who are proud and wicked in the church community?
options: We should be vigilant against pride and work to humble the proud and uphold righteousness.
We should tolerate pride to avoid conflict.
We should ignore wickedness and focus only on ourselves.
We should retaliate with pride ourselves.
questions.correctAnswer: We should be vigilant against pride and work to humble the proud and uphold righteousness.
questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes casting abroad wrath and bringing down the proud and wicked, encouraging active opposition to pride and evil (Job 40:11-12).

questions.question: What does Job 40:14 imply about human capability and reliance on God for salvation?
options: We must recognize our inability to save ourselves apart from God’s power.
Humans can always save themselves without God.
Salvation is based on human strength alone.
We should boast in our own righteousness.
questions.correctAnswer: We must recognize our inability to save ourselves apart from God’s power.
questions.explanation: God states He will confess that a person can save himself only if God allows it, underscoring human dependence on divine power (Job 40:14).

questions.question: How does the portrayal of Behemoth in Job 40:17-18 encourage believers to trust in God’s design and power?
options: It highlights the impressive strength and design only God can give, inspiring trust in His sovereignty.
It suggests that creatures are weak and unreliable.
It teaches self-reliance instead of trust in God.
It shows that power is unimportant in God’s creation.
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the impressive strength and design only God can give, inspiring trust in His sovereignty.
questions.explanation: The strong bones and mighty tail of Behemoth illustrate God’s creative power, encouraging trust in His design (Job 40:17-18).

questions.question: What practical spiritual lesson can be drawn from Job 40:24 about facing traps or snares in life?
options: We should be watchful and discerning to avoid dangers, trusting God’s protection.
We should ignore dangers and traps.
We should fall into snares without concern.
We should rely on others to keep us safe without personal vigilance.
questions.correctAnswer: We should be watchful and discerning to avoid dangers, trusting God’s protection.
questions.explanation: Behemoth perceives snares with his eyes and nose, teaching vigilance and trust in God’s safeguarding (Job 40:24).

hard.title: Job Chapter 40 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 40.

questions.question: In Job 40:2, what is the LORD challenging Job not to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Instruct the Almighty
questions.explanation: Job 40:2 challenges those who contend with or reprove God to answer, highlighting the folly of instructing the Almighty.

questions.question: What is Job's response to the LORD's challenge in Job 40:4?
options: I am vile; what shall I answer thee?
questions.correctAnswer: I am vile; what shall I answer thee?
questions.explanation: Job 40:4 records Job acknowledging his lowliness and choosing silence, indicating humility before God's majesty.

questions.question: In Job 40:7, the LORD commands Job to 'gird up thy loins like a man.' What literary device is primarily used in this command?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The phrase 'like a man' in Job 40:7 is a simile, comparing girding one's loins to manly readiness for action.

questions.question: According to Job 40:9, what two attributes of God does the LORD question Job about possessing?
options: An arm like God and a voice that can thunder
Eyes that see all and hands that heal
questions.correctAnswer: An arm like God and a voice that can thunder
questions.explanation: Job 40:9 questions whether Job has an arm like God or can thunder with a voice like Him, emphasizing God's unique power.

questions.question: In Job 40:10, what imagery is used to describe how Job should 'deck himself'?
options: Majesty and excellency, glory and beauty
questions.correctAnswer: Majesty and excellency, glory and beauty
questions.explanation: The LORD instructs Job in Job 40:10 to clothe himself with majesty, excellency, glory, and beauty, symbolizing divine authority and splendor.

questions.question: What is the primary theme expressed in Job 40:11-14 regarding pride?
options: The abasing of the proud and wicked
questions.correctAnswer: The abasing of the proud and wicked
questions.explanation: Verses 11 to 14 emphasize bringing low the proud and wicked, highlighting God's judgment against arrogance.

questions.question: The creature described in Job 40:15-24 is called 'behemoth.' What is the significance of this creature in the context of ancient Near Eastern literature?
options: It represents a primeval chaotic beast symbolizing God's creative power
It is a mythical dragon defeated by the hero
It is a symbol for the enemies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It represents a primeval chaotic beast symbolizing God's creative power
questions.explanation: Behemoth in Job 40:15-24 is depicted as a powerful, untamable creature, often interpreted as a symbol of primeval chaos subdued by God, reflecting themes in ancient Near Eastern mythology.

questions.question: Which of the following descriptions is NOT used for behemoth in Job 40:16-18?
questions.correctAnswer: Wings like an eagle
questions.explanation: Job 40:16-18 describes behemoth's tail, bones, and strength but does not mention wings, making 'wings like an eagle' incorrect.

questions.question: In Job 40:19, behemoth is called 'the chief of the ways of God.' What theological implication does this title carry?
options: Behemoth exemplifies the pinnacle of God's creation and power
questions.correctAnswer: Behemoth exemplifies the pinnacle of God's creation and power
questions.explanation: The phrase in Job 40:19 suggests behemoth is a supreme example of God's creative might, underscoring God's sovereignty over all creation.

questions.question: The imagery of behemoth drinking up a river and hastening not (Job 40:23) serves as a literary device to emphasize what?
options: Its role as a water deity
questions.correctAnswer: Its immense power and confidence
questions.explanation: Job 40:23 uses hyperbole to portray behemoth's mighty, unhurried strength, symbolizing confidence and dominion over natural forces.

questions.question: Which Old Testament book contains a similar motif of God confronting human pride as seen in Job 40:8-14?
questions.correctAnswer: Proverbs
questions.explanation: Proverbs frequently addresses the theme of pride being humbled (e.g., Proverbs 16:18), paralleled by the Lord's admonition to Job in Job 40:8-14.

questions.question: The dialogue in Job 40, especially verses 6-14, exemplifies which literary structure common in Hebrew poetry?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The structure of God's speech in Job 40:6-14 shows chiastic arrangement, centering on themes of judgment and human pride.

questions.question: In the cultural context of the ancient Near East, the whirlwind from which God speaks in Job 40:6 is often associated with what?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine presence and power
questions.explanation: The whirlwind in Job 40:6 symbolizes God's majestic and fearful presence, a motif common in ancient Near Eastern religious texts.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the theme of God’s sovereignty over creation seen in Job 40's description of behemoth?
questions.correctAnswer: Colossians 1:16-17
questions.explanation: Colossians 1:16-17 emphasizes Christ’s role in creation and sustaining all things, paralleling Job 40’s emphasis on God’s sovereign creation power.

questions.question: True or False: In Job 40:14, God states that if Job brings the proud low, God will confess that Job's right hand can save him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 40:14 says God will acknowledge Job's saving power if he can humble the proud, underscoring human limitation versus divine power.

theological.title: Job Chapter 40 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 40 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Job 40, what challenge does God present to Job regarding his ability to contend with the Almighty?
options: Do you have an arm like God or can you thunder like Him?
Can you forgive sins like the Messiah?
Will you build the heavens with the Spirit's guidance?
Can you calm the sea as Jesus did?
questions.correctAnswer: Do you have an arm like God or can you thunder like Him?
questions.explanation: Job 40:9 explicitly questions Job's power compared to God's, challenging human ability to contend with divine attributes. This reflects God's incomparable power as seen also in Psalm 89:9, Isaiah 40:12, Jeremiah 10:12, and John 1:3.

questions.question: What is Job's response after God begins His discourse in Job 40?
options: I am vile; I will lay my hand upon my mouth.
I can justify myself before You.
questions.correctAnswer: I am vile; I will lay my hand upon my mouth.
questions.explanation: In Job 40:4, Job acknowledges his lowly state and chooses silence, signifying human humility before divine majesty, consistent with Proverbs 3:7, Isaiah 66:2, Micah 6:8, and James 4:6.

questions.question: According to Job 40, what does God demand Job to do before questioning Him?
options: Gird up thy loins like a man and prepare to answer.
Pray for wisdom from the Holy Spirit.
Seek the counsel of the elders.
questions.correctAnswer: Gird up thy loins like a man and prepare to answer.
questions.explanation: Job 40:7 calls Job to prepare himself like a man, symbolizing readiness and courage before God's judgment, paralleling themes in 1 Corinthians 16:13, Ephesians 6:11, Proverbs 27:17, and 2 Timothy 2:3.

questions.question: What does God say about His judgment in Job 40:8?
options: Will you disannul My judgment and condemn Me to be righteous?
My judgment is flawed and needs your correction.
I will judge only those who sin.
My judgment is hidden and unknowable.
questions.correctAnswer: Will you disannul My judgment and condemn Me to be righteous?
questions.explanation: Job 40:8 highlights God's sovereign and righteous judgment, rejecting human attempts to reverse divine justice. This aligns with Romans 9:20-21, Isaiah 55:8-9, Psalm 50:6, and Hebrews 12:29.

questions.question: In the description of Behemoth, which feature is emphasized as a symbol of great strength?
options: He moveth his tail like a cedar.
questions.correctAnswer: He moveth his tail like a cedar.
questions.explanation: Job 40:17 metaphorically describes Behemoth's tail like a cedar tree, symbolizing immense power and majestic strength, comparable to the strength attributed to Leviathan in Job 41:24, and God's creative power in Psalm 104:26, Isaiah 40:31, and Ezekiel 32:2.

questions.question: What is the significance of God's question about Job's ability to 'thunder with a voice like Him' in Job 40:9?
options: It reveals God's unique authority over nature and judgment.
It challenges Job to perform miracles.
It calls Job to lead Israel in worship.
It invites Job to prophesy about the Messiah.
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals God's unique authority over nature and judgment.
questions.explanation: The question in Job 40:9 emphasizes God's sovereign control over creation and His authority to execute judgment, a theme echoed in Exodus 19:16-19, Psalm 29:3-9, Nahum 1:3, and Hebrews 12:26.

questions.question: According to Job 40:11-12, what attitude toward the proud and wicked does God express?
options: God commands to abase the proud and tread down the wicked.
God urges to forgive the proud and love the wicked.
God instructs to ignore the proud and punish the wicked later.
God encourages to teach the proud humility and the wicked righteousness.
questions.correctAnswer: God commands to abase the proud and tread down the wicked.
questions.explanation: Job 40:11-12 portrays God's judgment against pride and wickedness, consistent with Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 2:12, James 4:6, and 1 Peter 5:5 which warn against pride and affirm God's opposition to the proud.

questions.question: What theological truth is taught by God's reference to Behemoth as 'he that made him can make his sword to approach unto him' (Job 40:19)?
options: God is sovereign over all creation, including its power and dominion.
Behemoth is invincible and beyond God's control.
Man must protect Behemoth from harm.
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign over all creation, including its power and dominion.
questions.explanation: Job 40:19 emphasizes God's sovereignty over even the mightiest creatures, reinforcing the biblical doctrine of divine omnipotence as seen also in Colossians 1:16-17, Psalm 103:19, Isaiah 45:7, and Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: How does Job 40 portray human limitations in comparison to God's majesty and power?
options: Humans cannot contend with God or overturn His righteous judgment.
Humans have equal authority to judge God.
Humans can create like God if given enough power.
Humans are God’s partners in creation and judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: Humans cannot contend with God or overturn His righteous judgment.
questions.explanation: Job 40:2 and 40:8 make clear the impossibility of humans instructing or condemning God, emphasizing divine sovereignty and human humility, supported by Isaiah 55:8-9, Romans 9:20, Job 42:2, and Psalm 115:3.

questions.question: What does God's description of Behemoth eating grass "as an ox" (Job 40:15) suggest about this creature's nature?
options: It is a powerful, yet peaceful part of God's creation.
It is a carnivorous beast of prey.
It is a mythical creature with destructive power.
It is a symbol of chaos and evil.
questions.correctAnswer: It is a powerful, yet peaceful part of God's creation.
questions.explanation: Job 40:15 characterizes Behemoth as a herbivore, signifying strength combined with peace, reflecting God's diverse creative design seen in Genesis 1:29-30, Psalm 104:14-15, Isaiah 11:6-7, and Romans 8:19-22.

questions.question: Which aspect of God's character is most prominently revealed in His speech from the whirlwind in Job 40?
options: His omnipotence and righteous judgment over creation.
His mercy and willingness to forgive immediately.
His dependence on human counsel for decisions.
questions.correctAnswer: His omnipotence and righteous judgment over creation.
questions.explanation: God's voice from the whirlwind (Job 40:6) symbolizes divine power and authority, affirming His sovereign judgment, in line with Psalm 18:7-15, Nahum 1:3, Exodus 19:18, and Hebrews 12:29.

questions.question: In Job 40:23, what is significant about Behemoth drinking up a river and hastening not?
options: It demonstrates confidence in God's provision and control over nature.
It indicates Behemoth's fear of the water.
It shows Behemoth’s vulnerability to predators.
It symbolizes human impatience with divine timing.
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates confidence in God's provision and control over nature.
questions.explanation: The passage in Job 40:23 portrays Behemoth’s fearless reliance on natural resources, reflecting God's sustaining power as described in Psalm 104:10-13, Isaiah 40:11, Matthew 6:26, and Philippians 4:19.

questions.question: What does God imply about human power in Job 40:14 when He says, 'Then will I also confess unto thee that thine own right hand can save thee'?
options: Only when humans demonstrate divine-like power will God acknowledge their strength.
Humans can save themselves without God.
God always admits human power is sufficient.
Humans are equal to God in power.
questions.correctAnswer: Only when humans demonstrate divine-like power will God acknowledge their strength.
questions.explanation: Job 40:14 stresses that human power is insufficient unless it mirrors God's, teaching reliance on divine strength, consistent with John 15:5, Psalm 127:1, Isaiah 40:29, and 2 Corinthians 12:9.

questions.question: The phrase 'Behold now behemoth, which I made with thee' (Job 40:15) communicates which theological truth?
options: God shares creative authority with humanity.
Behemoth is a symbol of human pride.
God alone is Creator of all living things including Behemoth.
Behemoth represents evil in the world.
questions.correctAnswer: God alone is Creator of all living things including Behemoth.
questions.explanation: The verse affirms God's exclusive role as Creator, underscoring His sovereignty over creation, echoed in Genesis 1:1, Psalm 104:24, Isaiah 45:12, and Colossians 1:16.

questions.question: What does the imagery of 'hide them in the dust together; and bind their faces in secret' (Job 40:13) reveal about God's judgment?
options: God's judgment is both decisive and often hidden from human view.
God's judgment is public and immediate.
God spares the wicked from punishment.
God lets humans execute judgment without His intervention.
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment is both decisive and often hidden from human view.
questions.explanation: Job 40:13 portrays God's sovereign and sometimes secret judgment, consistent with Ecclesiastes 12:14, Romans 2:16, Hebrews 4:13, and Revelation 20:12.
